title: How to Prepare a Vegan Thanksgiving Dinner

steps.headline: Prepare a vegan soup.
steps.description: Combine chopped vegetables into a saucepan, add vegetable stock, and simmer until the vegetables are soft. Start with a base of chopped onions, carrots, and celery. Sauté until soft, and then add a few cloves of garlic if you'd like. Add the primary vegetable. For example, add 1 pound (454 kg) of broccoli for every 4 people who will enjoy the soup. Pour the vegetable broth into the saucepan, and simmer until the vegetables have softened, which is about 20 minutes. Use 3 cups (680 g) of stock for every 4 people. Add seasonings, such as a bay leaf, salt, and pepper to the soup as it simmers.

steps.headline: Puree the soup with an immersion blender.
Make vegan sides for Thanksgiving dinner.
steps.description: Slice sweet potatoes or root vegetables such as turnips and beets into 1/4-inch (.64-cm) rounds. Toss with olive oil.

steps.headline: Spread the cut vegetables out on a baking sheet in a single layer.
Roast the vegetables in an oven at 450 degree Fahrenheit (232 degrees Celsius) for 20 minutes.
Boil peeled and cubed potatoes in a saucepan for 25 minutes until the potatoes are very tender and falling apart to make mashed potatoes.
Drain the potatoes, then push through a ricer or mash with a potato masher.
Add soy milk and margarine, and stir until the potatoes have absorbed the milk and fat.
steps.description: Season to taste with salt and pepper.

steps.headline: Make vegan Thanksgiving stuffing by sauteing a chopped onion, chopped carrot, and chopped celery stalk.
steps.description: Double the number of vegetables for every 6 people.

steps.headline: Stir in 1 pound (454 kg) of bread cubes for every 6 people you plan on serving.
Pour 2 cups (454 g) vegetable stock over the bread and vegetable mixture and let it soak for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Add dried herbs, such as sage or rosemary to the stuffing mix. You can also mix in fried vegan "sausage."

steps.headline: Transfer to a baking dish, and bake in an oven set at 350 degree Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) for about 20 minutes.
Make a vegan pumpkin pie by using a pre made vegan pie crust.
steps.description: Check the ingredients to make sure there are no lard or other animal ingredients in the crust. You can also make your favorite pie crust recipe vegan by using margarine and shortening instead of butter.

steps.headline: Replace the ingredients in your favorite pumpkin pie recipe with non-dairy alternatives.
steps.description: For example, use soy milk with a bit of cornstarch mixed in instead of evaporated milk.

steps.headline: Serve a vegan "turkey" if you think your guests will enjoy it.
steps.description: Some vegans do not like to eat imitation meat while many omnivores are also turned off by the idea of fake meat. Only serve a mock-turkey if you know guests will enjoy it.

steps.headline: Try serving a vegetable-based stew or pot pie as the main dish.
steps.description: Cube tofu, and Sauté it until golden. Add it to the stew for an extra amount of protein.

steps.headline: Use a vegan pie crust or vegan puff pastry if you make a pot pie.

text: Vegan Thanksgiving Sides and Starters Prepare a vegan soup. Combine chopped vegetables into a saucepan, add vegetable stock, and simmer until the vegetables are soft. Start with a base of chopped onions, carrots, and celery. Sauté until soft, and then add a few cloves of garlic if you'd like. Add the primary vegetable. For example, add 1 pound (454 kg) of broccoli for every 4 people who will enjoy the soup. Pour the vegetable broth into the saucepan, and simmer until the vegetables have softened, which is about 20 minutes. Use 3 cups (680 g) of stock for every 4 people. Add seasonings, such as a bay leaf, salt, and pepper to the soup as it simmers. Puree the soup with an immersion blender.  Make vegan sides for Thanksgiving dinner. Slice sweet potatoes or root vegetables such as turnips and beets into 1/4-inch (.64-cm) rounds. Toss with olive oil. Spread the cut vegetables out on a baking sheet in a single layer. Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Roast the vegetables in an oven at 450 degree Fahrenheit (232 degrees Celsius) for 20 minutes.  Boil peeled and cubed potatoes in a saucepan for 25 minutes until the potatoes are very tender and falling apart to make mashed potatoes.  Drain the potatoes, then push through a ricer or mash with a potato masher.  Add soy milk and margarine, and stir until the potatoes have absorbed the milk and fat. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Make vegan Thanksgiving stuffing by sauteing a chopped onion, chopped carrot, and chopped celery stalk. Double the number of vegetables for every 6 people. Stir in 1 pound (454 kg) of bread cubes for every 6 people you plan on serving.  Pour 2 cups (454 g) vegetable stock over the bread and vegetable mixture and let it soak for 5 minutes. Add dried herbs, such as sage or rosemary to the stuffing mix. You can also mix in fried vegan "sausage." Transfer to a baking dish, and bake in an oven set at 350 degree Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) for about 20 minutes.  Vegan Thanksgiving Dessert Make a vegan pumpkin pie by using a pre made vegan pie crust. Check the ingredients to make sure there are no lard or other animal ingredients in the crust. You can also make your favorite pie crust recipe vegan by using margarine and shortening instead of butter. Replace the ingredients in your favorite pumpkin pie recipe with non-dairy alternatives. For example, use soy milk with a bit of cornstarch mixed in instead of evaporated milk. Vegan Main Dish Serve a vegan "turkey" if you think your guests will enjoy it. Some vegans do not like to eat imitation meat while many omnivores are also turned off by the idea of fake meat. Only serve a mock-turkey if you know guests will enjoy it. Try serving a vegetable-based stew or pot pie as the main dish. Cube tofu, and Sauté it until golden. Add it to the stew for an extra amount of protein. Use a vegan pie crust or vegan puff pastry if you make a pot pie.
